conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the circuit both when the switch is open and when it is closed.
Analyze the circuit when the switch is open.
When the switch is open, the circuit consists only of the resistance R1 and the ammeter.
The voltage U is applied across R1, and the current through the circuit is given as I0 = 0.5 A.
Using Ohm's law, U = I0 * R1 = 0.5 A * 20 Ω = 10 V
Analyze the circuit when the switch is closed.
When the switch is closed, the circuit consists of the resistance R1 in series with the motor M.
The voltage across the circuit remains the same, so U = 10 V.
The total resistance in the circuit is R_total = R1 + R2 = 20 Ω + 10 Ω = 30 Ω.
The current through the circuit when the switch is closed is I = U / R_total = 10 V / 30 Ω = 1/3 A.
The power consumed by the circuit is P = U * I = 10 V * 1/3 A = 10/3 W ≈ 3.33 W.
The power consumed by the circuit when the switch is closed is 10/3 W, which is approximately 3.33 W. This is much less than 15 W.
The relationship between the electric power P consumed by the circuit and 15 W is P < 15 W.
